study_goal: To investigate the relationship between plasma lutein and zeaxanthin concentrations and the prevalence of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in adults aged 50 and over.
results_summary: Higher plasma lutein concentrations were significantly associated with AMD status, particularly in groups aware of their condition or incorrectly believing they had AMD. Supplement use was more common in these groups, correlating with elevated lutein levels.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 50 years and over in the Republic of Ireland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 20 mg lutein supplementation (using two different capsule types) on macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and plasma lutein concentration in patients with unilateral age-related macular degeneration, while also assessing factors influencing baseline plasma lutein levels.
results_summary: Lutein supplementation significantly increased plasma lutein concentrations in both groups, but only the beeswax capsule group showed a marginally significant increase in MPOD. Age negatively correlated with plasma lutein levels, while green vegetable consumption positively influenced baseline concentrations.
population_specificity: 39 Japanese patients with unilateral age-related macular degeneration.

study_goal: To investigate whether antioxidant supplementation containing lutein improves functional and morphological outcomes in patients with chronic central serous chorioretinopathy compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The supplementation group showed significant improvement in best-corrected visual acuity (p = 0.003) and a 28.6% reduction in subfoveal fluid height (p = 0.028), while the placebo group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 100 patients (79 completed) with chronic central serous chorioretinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a new formulation technology (mixture of mono- and diglycerides) affects lutein absorption compared to high-oleic safflower oil.
results_summary: The study found that lutein absorption was significantly higher with the MDG formulation compared to SAF, with greater changes in plasma lutein levels and higher AUC values at 48 and 336 hours. The MDG group showed 129% and 320% higher plasma lutein levels at 12 and 48 hours, respectively, and 232% and 900% higher AUC values for 0-48 and 0-336 hours.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (n=24)
study_duration: Single dose with follow-up measurements up to 336 hours (14 days)

study_goal: To compare changes in macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and serum lutein concentration between free lutein and lutein esters supplements in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Both free lutein and lutein esters significantly increased serum lutein concentrations and MPOD levels, with no significant differences between the two forms. The effects persisted for MPOD but not serum lutein three months after supplementation ended.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese individuals aged 22-47 years.
effective_dosage: 10 mg free lutein or 20 mg lutein esters (equivalent to 10 mg free lutein) daily.
study_duration: 3 months of supplementation, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a solid-lipid particle (SLP) lutein complex versus conventional lutein ester on serum lutein accumulation in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The SLP lutein complex resulted in significantly higher plasma lutein levels than conventional lutein ester, both after 10 days of supplementation and 7 days post-discontinuation. The complex showed superior efficacy in absolute mean values, change from baseline, and sustained levels after stopping supplementation.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy people

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation of an epilutein/lutein combination could increase macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in patients with early-stage age-related macular degeneration (AMD) compared to lutein alone.
results_summary: The study found that the epilutein/lutein combination increased MPOD significantly at 1 and 2 months, while lutein alone showed a reduction in MPOD at 1 month and a slight increase at 2 months. Systemic xanthophyll levels rose in both groups at 1 month but were significantly higher only in the combination group at 2 months.
population_specificity: Patients with early-stage AMD (mean age ~69-72 years).
effective_dosage: Group 1: 8 mg epilutein + 2 mg lutein daily; Group 2: 10 mg lutein daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different macular carotenoid formulations, including lutein, on macular pigment and visual function in early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: All supplementation groups showed significant increases in macular pigment, with Group 3 (containing meso-zeaxanthin) demonstrating the most consistent improvements. Contrast sensitivity improved in all groups, but no significant changes in visual acuity or AMD progression were observed.
population_specificity: 67 subjects with early AMD.
effective_dosage: Group 1: 20 mg/day lutein; Group 2: 10 mg/day lutein; Group 3: 3 mg/day lutein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lutein supplementation affects systemic complement activation in elderly individuals with early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: Lutein supplementation significantly reduced plasma sC5b-9 levels by 1.1 ng/ml monthly over 12 months, while the placebo group showed a significant increase of 0.6 ng/ml monthly. The findings suggest lutein inhibits systemic complement activation, supporting its potential benefits in AMD management.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with early signs of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of lutein supplementation on plasma lutein concentrations and macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in patients with central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC).
results_summary: Lutein supplementation significantly increased plasma lutein concentrations but did not significantly increase MPOD in CSC patients. However, in patients with low baseline plasma lutein, supplementation prevented a decline in MPOD observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 39 patients with central serous chorioretinopathy (20 in lutein group, 19 in placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the macular response to different lutein-containing supplements in normal subjects and those with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: MPOD increased significantly at all eccentricities in each group, with serum MZ concentrations strongly correlated with MPOD after 8 weeks, particularly in group 3 (3 mg L, 2 mg Z, 17 mg MZ). Group 2 (10 mg L, 2 mg Z, 10 mg MZ) showed greater MPOD augmentation across the spatial profile, suggesting L inclusion may enhance effects.
population_specificity: Normal subjects (n=31) and AMD subjects (n=32).
effective_dosage: Group 1 (20 mg L, 2 mg Z, 0.3 mg MZ), Group 2 (10 mg L, 2 mg Z, 10 mg MZ), Group 3 (3 mg L, 2 mg Z, 17 mg MZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the interindividual variability in lutein bioavailability in humans, assess its relation to fasting blood lutein concentration, and identify genetic polymorphisms involved in this variability.
results_summary: The study found high variability in postprandial chylomicron lutein responses, which were positively correlated between meals and with fasting plasma lutein concentration. A combination of 29 SNPs in 15 genes explained most of the variance in lutein response, suggesting a genetic basis for lutein bioavailability.
population_specificity: 39 healthy men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lutein supplementation on serum cytokines, apoE, and lipoprotein profiles in individuals with early atherosclerosis.
results_summary: Lutein supplementation significantly increased serum lutein levels, reduced inflammatory cytokines (IL-6 and MCP-1), and lowered LDL and triglyceride levels in the treatment group. The changes in serum lutein were negatively correlated with LDL levels, suggesting a potential regulatory role in lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Early atherosclerosis patients (n=65)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily lutein supplementation could improve macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and visual acuity (VA) in patients with early age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: Lutein supplementation significantly increased MPOD levels in early AMD patients and showed potential to slow disease progression in a subgroup with worse baseline VA, while the placebo group experienced deterioration in VA.
population_specificity: 72 patients (mean age 70.5 ± 8.7) with early age-related macular degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein supplementation affects activation of the complement system, specifically measuring changes in complement factors CFD, C5a, and C3d in individuals with early macular degeneration.
results_summary: Lutein supplementation significantly decreased plasma levels of CFD (51% reduction), C5a (36% reduction), and C3d (9% reduction) over 12 months, suggesting a systemic anti-inflammatory effect on the complement pathway. No significant changes were observed in the placebo group for C5a and C3d, though a minor decrease in CFD occurred.
population_specificity: 72 subjects with signs of early macular degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein or zeaxanthin supplementation affects macular pigment concentration/optical density (MPOD) in healthy Japanese individuals.
results_summary: Lutein supplementation increased MPOD levels by >20% from baseline at 2 and 3 months in individuals without high myopia, while zeaxanthin showed no significant change. The increase was not observed in individuals with high myopia.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese volunteers, including those with and without high myopia (exceeding -4 diopters).
effective_dosage: 10 mg of lutein or zeaxanthin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation could attenuate, amplify, or generate ring-like structures in macular pigment spatial profiles, which are inversely associated with age-related macular degeneration.
results_summary: Lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation increased macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in eyes without ring structures, with significant central and eccentricity-dependent improvements. However, ring structures were neither attenuated nor newly generated, suggesting stabilization of lutein and zeaxanthin in pericentral rather than central retinal locations in individuals with pre-existing secondary peaks or implied plateaus.
population_specificity: 97 subjects (with 11 eyes showing ring-like structures and 8 with implied pericentral plateaus/shoulders) from the LUNA study.
effective_dosage: 12 mg lutein and 1 mg zeaxanthin supplementation.
study_duration: 6 months of supplementation, with follow-up 3 months post-discontinuation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation could reduce the occurrence of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in ROP occurrence between the L/Z and placebo groups, with similar rates of ROP at each stage and no reduction in the need for eye surgery. L/Z supplementation was ineffective in preventing ROP in preterm infants.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age ≤32 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of different lutein supplement doses on serum lutein concentration and macular pigment optical density (MPOD).
results_summary: Serum lutein concentration and MPOD increased linearly with lutein dosage, reaching a plateau. No significant influence of age on lutein uptake or MPOD response was detected.
population_specificity: 87 subjects (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lutein diacetate and crystalline lutein supplements (both equivalent to 20 mg/day free lutein) versus placebo on serum lutein levels and macular pigment optical density (MPOD) over 24 weeks.
results_summary: Lutein diacetate (group 1) showed a 25% higher serum lutein response and 52% higher MPOD increase compared to crystalline lutein (group 2), both significantly outperforming placebo. The differences between groups 1 and 2 were marginally significant for serum (p = 0.066) and approaching significance for MPOD (p = 0.09).
population_specificity: 30 subjects (10 per group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein/zeaxanthin supplementation could influence the amount and pattern of macular pigment in patients with type 2 idiopathic telangiectasia.
results_summary: Supplementation increased macular pigment in areas where it was already present at baseline but did not restore it in areas where it was absent. The effect varied based on the baseline classification of macular pigment patterns.
population_specificity: Eleven patients with type 2 idiopathic telangiectasia.
effective_dosage: 12 mg lutein and 0.6 mg zeaxanthin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein supplementation could reduce the incidence and severity of Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found no differences in ROP incidence or severity between the lutein and placebo groups, suggesting lutein supplementation did not significantly impact ROP outcomes in this population. The authors hypothesized that oxidative injury may play only a minor role in ROP pathogenesis, and larger or higher-dose studies might be needed to detect potential benefits.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age ≤ 32 weeks who could tolerate minimal enteral feeding before the seventh day of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the 1-year changes in macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and visual function in response to daily supplementation containing 6 mg of lutein.
results_summary: Daily supplementation with 6 mg of lutein did not significantly increase MPOD levels over 1 year but improved visual functions such as contrast sensitivity and retinal sensitivity. Subjects without cardiovascular diseases showed higher increases in MPOD, and nonsmokers had increased contrast sensitivity.
population_specificity: 43 Japanese subjects, including normal eyes, fellow eyes with central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC), and fellow eyes with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene could mitigate TMAO-induced senescence of endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) via the AMPK/SIRT1 pathway.
results_summary: Lycopene alleviated TMAO-induced suppression of EPC functionality and reduced senescence markers, but these protective effects were reversed by inhibiting AMPK or SIRT1. The study suggests lycopene's role in counteracting TMAO-induced cellular aging.
population_specificity: Endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) in a laboratory setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of lycopene in Kaili Sour Soup (KSS) and its mechanism in ameliorating lipid metabolism abnormalities in NAFLD, particularly through estrogen signaling and lipid metabolism-related molecules.
results_summary: Lycopene, the major component of KSS, increased expression of ERα, CPT1A, PPARα, and HSL while reducing SREBP-1c, ACC, and LPL, indicating improved lipid metabolism and reduced hepatic fat accumulation. Both KSS and lycopene showed potential to lower lipid accumulation and enhance lipolysis.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (6-week-old) and HepG2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lycopene (Lyc) could mitigate cadmium (Cd)-induced cytotoxicity in EPC cells by examining its effects on miR-375, oxidative stress, actin cytoskeleton dysfunction, and glucose uptake ability.
results_summary: Lycopene alleviated Cd-induced increases in miR-375, oxidative stress, actin cytoskeleton dysfunction, and reductions in glucose uptake ability. The study identified miR-375-ROS/IRS1-PI3K-AKT and miR-375/IRS1-PI3K-AKT pathways as key mechanisms for Lyc's protective effects.
population_specificity: Epithelioma papulosum cyprini (EPC) cells, a model for studying carps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biochemical properties, antioxidant mechanisms, and protective effects of lycopene in kidney diseases, based on animal experiments and clinical studies.
results_summary: Lycopene demonstrated protective effects against kidney injury through anti-oxidative and anti-inflammatory mechanisms, reduced CKD incidence and mortality, and mitigated cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity. However, clinical studies on lycopene in renal diseases are limited.
population_specificity: Animal models and some CKD patients (specific human population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Lycopene (LYC) could protect against Doxorubicin (DOX)-induced heart failure by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and ferroptosis.
results_summary: LYC improved cardiac function by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and ferroptosis, primarily through activation of the Nrf2 signaling pathway and inhibition of MMP-2/9, p53, Bax, and c-Casp3.
population_specificity: Cardiomyocytes and C57BL/6J mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Lycopene (LYC) impacts polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and its action mechanisms, particularly focusing on ferroptosis inhibition and the AMPK/Nrf2 pathway.
results_summary: LYC dose-dependently ameliorated PCOS symptoms, including body weight, ovarian damage, and hormone levels, while reducing iron deposition and ferroptosis. It activated the AMPK/Nrf2 pathway, suggesting this as a key mechanism for its therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: PCOS-induced rat model.
effective_dosage: Different doses (specific amounts not provided) injected intraperitoneally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sulfur-containing compounds from different plant sources and heat treatments on lycopene isomerization and degradation to enhance its bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that allicin, alliin, and sulforaphane significantly increased Z-lycopene content (up to 77.1%) and improved bioaccessibility, particularly for 9-Z-lycopene and 5-Z-lycopene, without significantly affecting degradation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food system study)
effective_dosage: Not specified (used alliin-rich garlic juice at 21.20 mg/g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lycopene (LYC) could alleviate Atrazine (ATZ)- and diaminochlorotriazine (DACT)-induced ferroptosis in mouse hepatocytes and explore the regulatory role of Cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase (CYPOR) in this process.
results_summary: Lycopene inhibited CYPOR, reducing ATZ/DACT-induced Fe2+ accumulation and lipid peroxidation, thereby alleviating ferroptosis in mouse hepatocytes. CYPOR knockdown further enhanced LYC's protective effects, suggesting CYPOR as a novel therapeutic target for ferroptosis-related liver diseases.
population_specificity: Male mice and a mouse hepatocyte cell line (AML12).
effective_dosage: In vivo: 5 mg/kg LYC; in vitro: 2 μM LYC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which lycopene exerts its antidepressant effects, focusing on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus.
results_summary: Lycopene treatment (20 mg/kg) significantly improved synaptic deficits and reversed depressive-like behaviors in mice subjected to chronic social defeat stress (CSDS). It upregulated BDNF expression and reduced BDNF-TrkB/pTrkB pathway activity, suggesting enhanced synaptic plasticity via this signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with induced depressive-like behaviors using the CSDS model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene could mitigate paclitaxel-induced cognitive impairment in mice and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Lycopene (20 mg/kg) counteracted paclitaxel-induced cognitive impairment by reducing oxidative stress, endoplasmic reticulum stress, and neuroinflammation, as evidenced by improved behavioral function and histological markers.
population_specificity: Mice treated with paclitaxel
effective_dosage: 5, 10, and 20 mg/kg (20 mg/kg selected for mechanistic study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Lycopene's mechanisms in treating epididymitis, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects via the PI3K/AKT pathway.
results_summary: Lycopene improved epididymal pathology, reduced inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α), and inhibited PI3K/AKT activation, modulating inflammation and apoptosis while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: LPS-induced epididymitis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the allergenicity of malt protein Z (PZ) and its interaction with lycopene, focusing on whether PZ could improve lycopene's stability while reducing its allergenicity.
results_summary: The study found that PZ interacts with lycopene, reducing PZ's allergenicity (e.g., decreased IgE and mMcp-1 levels) and significantly improving lycopene's storage stability (retention increased from 14.9% to 65.5% over 10 days). The interaction also formed homogenous particles with enhanced zeta potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lycopene could protect against lung oxidative damage caused by PM_(2.5) exposure in rats.
results_summary: Lycopene, particularly at high doses (30 mg/kg), significantly improved antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced oxidative damage markers, and preserved lung tissue integrity compared to the PM_(2.5)-exposed control group. The effects were dose-dependent and comparable to vitamin E in mitigating PM_(2.5)-induced damage.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (7-week-old)
effective_dosage: Low (5 mg/kg), medium (15 mg/kg), and high (30 mg/kg) doses administered daily via gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lycopene's potential to improve male fertility by examining its effects on semen parameters, sex hormones, signaling pathways, and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that lycopene may improve sperm morphology, motility, and hormone regulation (testosterone, LH, FSH), while also offering antioxidant protection against oxidative stress, a key factor in male infertility. However, additional clinical data is needed to confirm these effects in humans.
population_specificity: Males with infertility concerns (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop Agriophyllum squarrosum starch nanoparticles (ASSNPs) to encapsulate lycopene (LYC) and enhance its stability and bioactivity under adverse conditions.
results_summary: The study found that ASSNPs successfully encapsulated LYC with high efficiency (64.3%), improved its stability, and provided superior protective effects during storage and digestion compared to unencapsulated LYC. Analytical techniques confirmed increased intermolecular interactions and structural integrity of the complex.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene could reduce postoperative abdominal adhesions in mice by mitigating inflammation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Lycopene (20 μg/kg) significantly reduced adhesion formation, inflammation, oxidative stress markers, and collagen deposition while promoting protective cellular pathways in mice. In vitro, lycopene protected mesothelial cells from oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Male Bagg's albino/c mice post-abdominal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lycopene on experimental giardiasis in mice, focusing on cyst shedding, weight changes, antioxidant status, and histopathological alterations.
results_summary: Lycopene at 20 mg/kg and mixed lycopene-metronidazole eliminated cyst shedding by the 7th day, with the mildest lesions observed in the mixed group. Lycopene-metronidazole significantly improved antioxidant status (increased TAC, decreased MDA) compared to controls, suggesting lycopene's antigiardial effect may relate to its antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: Male mice aged 4-6 weeks infected with Giardia duodenalis (B genotype).
effective_dosage: 5, 10, and 20 mg/kg lycopene, administered for 7 days.
interactions: Mixed lycopene-metronidazole showed enhanced effects, but no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lycopene could attenuate 5-FU-induced nephrotoxicity by restoring antioxidant activities and inhibiting inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Lycopene reduced renal dysfunction markers (urea, creatinine, uric acid, KIM-1) and improved antioxidant balance in a dose-dependent manner. It also modulated inflammatory markers (PPAR-γ, Nrf2/HO-1, NF-κB/TNF-α/IL-6) and prevented degenerative kidney changes caused by 5-FU.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lycopene's potential in preventing and treating metabolic syndrome, obesity, and type 2 diabetes due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The study found that lycopene exhibits strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, making it a promising candidate for improving metabolic health and reducing the risk of chronic diseases like metabolic syndrome, obesity, and type 2 diabetes. The findings were based on both animal and human studies.
population_specificity: Animal models and humans with metabolic syndrome, obesity, or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how lycopene ameliorates atrazine-induced hypothalamic injury, focusing on neural stem cell pluripotency and senescence pathways.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly reduced atrazine-induced hypothalamic damage, prevented neural stem cell senescence, and enhanced their proliferation and differentiation by inhibiting the ISR signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Mice and C17.2 neural stem cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cytotoxic effects of lycopene on HeLa cells by examining apoptosis, autophagy, and oxidative DNA damage.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly killed HeLa cells in a dose-dependent manner (IC50 = 10 μM), increased apoptotic protein expression (cleaved caspase 3, cleaved PARP, Bax), elevated oxidative DNA damage (8-oxo-dG), and activated autophagy (LC3β).
population_specificity: HeLa cells (human cervical cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the drug-drug interactions (DDI) of ponatinib with lycopene, focusing on pharmacokinetic changes and inhibition mechanisms.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly altered the pharmacokinetic parameters of ponatinib (AUC(0-t), AUC(0-∞), CLz/F) in animal experiments and showed a mixed inhibition mechanism on ponatinib metabolism in both rat and human liver microsomes.
population_specificity: Animal models (rats) and in vitro liver microsomes (rat and human).
interactions: Mixed inhibition mechanism with ponatinib metabolism in liver microsomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and underlying mechanisms of lycopene in managing digestive precancerous lesions, including its antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and regulatory effects on cell proliferation and apoptosis.
results_summary: Lycopene showed promise in managing digestive precancerous lesions, such as improving symptoms of oral submucous fibrosis (OSF), potentially matching steroids in treating oral lichen planus (OLP), and reducing colon cancer risk. Its mechanisms included antioxidative stress, anti-inflammatory responses, and regulation of cell proliferation and apoptosis, particularly via TLR4/TRIF/NF-κB and p53 pathways.
population_specificity: Individuals with digestive precancerous lesions (e.g., OPMDs, gastric ulcers, colorectal adenoma).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine lycopene's potential as an anti-inflammatory therapy for temporomandibular joint disorder.
results_summary: The abstract suggests lycopene may have analgesic properties for temporomandibular joint problems, but no specific results or outcomes are detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular joint disorder (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lycopene (LYC) on memory and behavioral deficits induced by D-galactose (D-gal) treatment and the role of LYC-derived gut microbiota in these processes.
results_summary: LYC showed effective protection against D-gal-induced cognitive deficits and neuronal damage, improved gut barrier function, and alleviated microbiota dysbiosis. Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) from LYC-treated mice and SCFAs supplementation similarly improved gut and brain function, suggesting LYC's benefits may be mediated via gut microbiota and SCFAs.
population_specificity: D-gal-induced subacute aging mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate lycopene's effect on testosterone synthesis in Leydig cells of laying breeder roosters and explore the underlying mechanisms involving MAPK-SF-1 and MAPK-Nrf2 pathways.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly increased testosterone secretion, antioxidant enzyme activity, and steroid-producing enzyme levels while reducing oxidative damage and apoptosis in Leydig cells. It also modulated the MAPK signaling pathway, enhancing JNK, SF-1, and Nrf2 expression while suppressing p38.
population_specificity: 55-week-old breeding roosters (poultry)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of lycopene on growth performance, meat quality, cecal microflora, and liver metabolome in broilers subjected to heat stress.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation improved growth performance, altered meat quality (e.g., increased pH, changed color values), modulated cecal microflora (increased beneficial bacteria), and induced significant changes in liver metabolome pathways in heat-stressed broilers.
population_specificity: Yellow feather broilers (poultry)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lycopene (LYC) on age-related memory impairment and the role of liver-brain FGF21 signaling in this process.
results_summary: LYC effectively managed brain aging and cognitive deficits, improved neuronal degeneration, mitochondrial function, and synaptic damage, and activated liver-brain FGF21 signaling in aging mice. These effects were negated when FGF21 was blocked, indicating its critical role in LYC's neuroprotective benefits.
population_specificity: 18-month-old mice (aging model) and mouse hippocampal HT-22 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lycopene could protect against renal damage caused by zearalenone (ZEN) in mice.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly reduced ZEN-induced renal damage by mitigating oxidative stress, apoptosis, and NLRP3 inflammasome activation, as evidenced by improved renal function markers and reduced pathological damage.
population_specificity: Male Kunming mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the ultrasound-assisted extraction (UAE) of lycopene from enzymatically treated tomato skins using green engineering principles and predictive modeling.
results_summary: The study achieved high lycopene yields (1018–1120 mg/kg) under optimal conditions, with an artificial neural network (ANN) model showing strong predictive accuracy (R=0.99914) and low error (RMSE=5.3 mg/kg). The k-Nearest Neighbor algorithm and SHAP methodology further validated the predictive modeling approach.
population_specificity: Tomato processing waste (skins, seeds, residual tissue)
study_duration: Extraction times varied (0–120 min), enzymatic reaction times (60–180 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate orange peel hydrolysate as a low-cost carbon source for lycopene production and optimize fermentation conditions to enhance lycopene yield.
results_summary: The study found that optimized conditions (5.53% orange peel hydrolysate, 6.57 g/L nitrogen source, 30°C) significantly boosted lycopene production (1043 mg/L). Lycopene extracted from orange peel hydrolysate demonstrated notable antioxidant capacity, as evidenced by DPPH radical scavenging activity.
population_specificity: Engineered Escherichia coli strain (in vitro study).
study_duration: Four-month adaptive laboratory evolution, followed by fermentation optimization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of LED lighting on tomato growth and nutritional value, specifically focusing on lycopene content in greenhouse-grown tomatoes under low daily light conditions.
results_summary: Intra-canopy LED lighting alone resulted in the highest increase in tomato lycopene content (31.3%), while combined top and intra-canopy lighting showed the highest increase in vitamin C content (123.4%). The study also noted positive effects on gene expression related to metabolic cycles.
population_specificity: Sakhiya RZ F1 tomato plants grown in a greenhouse with low daily light due to cloudy weather.
study_duration: Entire production year (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Lycopene extract, alone and in combination with Ascorbic Acid, on preserving the quality of fresh-cut apple slices during refrigeration.
results_summary: Lycopene (LC) and LC + Ascorbic Acid (AAC) treatments significantly reduced enzymatic activity compared to AAC alone, but LC + AAC did not preserve color due to high olive oil concentration. Physicochemical quality was better preserved in LC + AAC treatments.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut apple slices (Red Delicious variety)
effective_dosage: 100 mg Lycopene extract, 100 mg Ascorbic Acid

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene supplementation could mitigate oxidative stress and improve survival rates and parasitemia in mice infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA, compared to N-acetylcysteine (NAC).
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation slowed parasitemia development to 19% and increased survival rates to 80% in infected mice, outperforming NAC. The study suggests lycopene has a beneficial effect on malaria outcomes by reducing oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA (malaria model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of tomato peel as a source of lycopene and carotenoids for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that tomato peel extracts exhibit promising anticancer properties, suggesting potential therapeutic applications. The findings highlight the need for further research to explore lycopene's role in oncology.
population_specificity: Not specified (systematic review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound-healing potential of lycopene emulgel (LE) in diabetic rats and assess its properties.
results_summary: Lycopene emulgel (LE) significantly improved wound closure (95.3% and 88.9%) and epithelisation within 21 days in diabetic rats compared to controls. The formulation was deemed novel, safe, and effective for wound recovery.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats and control rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lycopene protects endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) from ox-LDL-induced damage and elucidate the underlying mechanism.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly enhanced proliferation, tube formation, and migration of ox-LDL-stimulated EPCs and suppressed pyroptosis via AMPK/mTOR/NLRP3 signaling. The study suggests lycopene may help prevent atherosclerosis.
population_specificity: Endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene combined with a reduced insulin dose could control glycemia and counteract glycoxidative stress in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Lycopene plus insulin effectively controlled glycemia, improved insulin sensitivity, reduced dyslipidemia, increased PON-1 activity, and enhanced kidney antioxidant defenses (SOD, CAT, AGE-R1, GLO-1), contributing to an antialbuminuric effect.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how lycopene affects macrophage immune responses, specifically its role in autophagy and immune enhancement.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly increased cell vitality, phagocytic activity, chemokine production, and activated the mTOR/Beclin1/LC3/p62 autophagy pathway in macrophages. These effects were reversed by inhibitors like necrostatin-1 and spautin-1, confirming RIPK1's role in the process.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells (a murine macrophage cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene could mitigate depression by blocking the 5-HT3 receptor and inhibiting IDO1 activity in mice.
results_summary: Lycopene reversed depression-like behavior in BCG-inoculated mice and restored serotonin and tryptophan levels. Its antidepressant effects were enhanced when combined with ondansetron or minocycline.
population_specificity: BCG-inoculated mice with induced depression-like phenotypes.
interactions: Enhanced effects when combined with ondansetron or minocycline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between specific genetic variants (SNPs) and skin and plasma carotenoid concentrations before and after a lycopene-rich tomato juice intervention.
results_summary: The study found that certain genetic variants (CD36 rs1527479 and BCO1 rs7500996) were significantly associated with skin carotenoid concentrations, suggesting genetic influences on carotenoid metabolism. The intervention increased carotenoid levels, with dosage-dependent effects observed.
population_specificity: 80 participants in a randomized, controlled trial.
effective_dosage: Low (13.1 mg), medium (23.9 mg), and high (31.0 mg) daily total carotenoid doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene (LYC) could attenuate osteoporotic bone loss by regulating redox homeostasis and influencing osteogenesis and adipogenesis.
results_summary: LYC reduced body weight gain, improved lipid metabolism, preserved bone quality, inhibited ROS overgeneration, and promoted osteogenesis while inhibiting adipogenesis in OVX rats and BMSCs. These effects were mediated via the FoxO1/PPARγ pathway.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) rats and bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining lycopene with sorafenib enhances antitumor effects compared to either treatment alone in breast cancer models.
results_summary: The combination of lycopene and sorafenib was more effective than monotherapy in inducing cell cycle arrest, reducing cancer cell viability, and increasing apoptosis and autophagy. It also modulated key proteins and genes related to tumor growth and inflammation.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells and mice with SEC (specific cancer model not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of lycopene supplementation during in vitro maturation (IVM) on oocyte maturation, fertilization, and developmental parameters, particularly its efficacy in reducing polyspermy rates.
results_summary: Lycopene improved IVF efficiency and reduced polyspermy rates in one bull (bull 1) but showed no effect in the other two bulls. The reduction in polyspermy was not linked to changes in cortical granule migration or mitochondrial distribution, suggesting lycopene induces other oocyte changes.
population_specificity: Bovine oocytes fertilized with semen from three bulls.
study_duration: Duration of IVM not specified in abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize ultrasound pre-treatment conditions for encapsulating lycopene and evaluate the properties of the resulting lycopene inclusion complex.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound pretreatment significantly improved the encapsulation efficiency (76.12%), antioxidant activity (92.20% DPPH scavenging rate), and storage stability of the lycopene inclusion complex. The complex also exhibited enhanced thermal properties and microstructure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of lycopene on macrophage polarization states in E. coli-induced mastitis, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties.
results_summary: Lycopene (0.5 μmol/L) enhanced cell viability and reduced inflammatory markers (LDH, iNOS, CD86, TNF-α, IL-1β, PTEN) while increasing M2 macrophage markers (CD206, ARG1, IDO, YM1) and activating the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. Higher doses (2-3 μmol/L) increased LDH activity, suggesting dose-dependent effects.
population_specificity: Macrophages in an in vitro model of E. coli-induced bovine mastitis.
study_duration: 24 hours pre-treatment with lycopene, followed by 6 hours of E. coli inoculation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of lycopene against calcium oxalate-induced kidney injury and identify its mechanisms and molecular targets.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly reduced crystal deposition, oxidative stress, inflammation, fibrosis, pyroptosis, and apoptosis in rat and cell models, with Trappc4 identified as a key target gene mediating these effects via the ERK1/2/AMPK pathway.
population_specificity: CaOx rat model and oxalate-stimulated NRK-52E and HK-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dual protective roles of carotenoids, including lycopene, in maintaining skin barrier function and antioxidant protection in the stratum corneum, particularly in the context of chemotherapy-induced PPE.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids, including lycopene, provide antioxidant protection and support skin barrier integrity by organizing intercellular lipids, potentially mitigating chemotherapy-induced PPE. The reduction of carotenoids in the stratum corneum during chemotherapy weakens skin resistance to adverse reactions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing chemotherapy (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the optimal dose of synthetic lycopene in combination with docetaxel and androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) and evaluate its safety and pharmacokinetic effects in men with metastatic prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found that 150 mg/day of lycopene was the maximum tolerated dose, with low toxicity and favorable pharmacokinetics. Lycopene increased plasma docetaxel exposure and showed dose-related effects on biomarkers related to angiogenesis and insulin-like growth factor signaling.
population_specificity: Men with metastatic prostate cancer.
study_duration: Administered in 21-day cycles (specific total duration not stated).
interactions: Increased plasma exposure to docetaxel when co-administered with lycopene.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lycopene's antimalarial activity against chloroquine-resistant malaria and its ability to ameliorate hematological abnormalities associated with malaria infection.
results_summary: Lycopene demonstrated significant antimalarial activity and improved hematological abnormalities in acute malaria infection, suggesting its potential as a novel antimalarial agent.
population_specificity: Experimental animals (Plasmodium berghei-infected mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test lycopene's intervention effect on colitis in mice and investigate its mechanism in blocking E. coli adhesion to intestinal epithelial cells.
results_summary: Lycopene attenuated DSS-induced colitis, reduced E. coli proportion, and modulated inflammatory pathways. It also inhibited E. coli O157:H7 adhesion to Caco-2 cells by blocking integrin β1 interaction.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced colitis and Caco-2 cells (human intestinal epithelial cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lycopene (LYC) could prevent or treat cardiorenal syndrome (CRS) induced by Atrazine (ATZ) by targeting MAPK/NF-κB signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study found that ATZ exposure caused cardiorenal injury and CRS, mediated by NF-κB and MAPK signaling pathways. LYC co-treatment reversed these effects, suggesting its potential as a preventive and therapeutic agent for CRS.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant effect of lycopene as an adjuvant treatment for periodontal disease compared to conventional treatment alone.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found statistically significant improvements in plaque index, probing pocket depth (short-term), bleeding on probing (short- and medium-term), and gingival index (short- and medium-term), but heterogeneity was high in most assessments.
population_specificity: Subjects with periodontal disease undergoing conventional treatment.
study_duration: Varied (short-, medium-, and long-term follow-ups, but exact durations not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the anti-inflammatory effects of tomato, tomato-derived products, and lycopene in the context of metabolic inflammation linked to cardiometabolic diseases.
results_summary: Animal and in vitro studies support the anti-inflammatory potential of tomato and tomato-derived products, but human intervention studies show mixed results, with no clear evidence favoring pure lycopene's anti-inflammatory effects. Observational studies suggest an inverse association between plasma lycopene levels and inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on metabolic inflammation and cardiometabolic diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which lycopene alleviates hypoxia-induced spermatocyte injury, focusing on the miR-23a/b-PROK2 pathway.
results_summary: Lycopene reduced hypoxia-induced apoptosis in GC-2 cells and increased miR-23a/b expression in vivo and in vitro. miR-23a/b mimics also reduced apoptosis by directly binding and downregulating PROK2 mRNA.
population_specificity: GC-2 cells (spermatocytes) and varicocele rat models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene could regulate gut microbiota and exert anti-atherosclerotic effects by modulating the "gut-heart" axis.
results_summary: Lycopene reduced atherosclerotic lesions, improved gut microbiota composition (e.g., increased Verrucomicrobia and Akkermansia), enhanced intestinal barrier function, and lowered inflammatory markers (e.g., TNF-α, IL-6) and serum LPS levels.
population_specificity: Male ApoE-/- mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an encapsulated Lycopene formula and investigate its effects on inflammatory markers, oxidative stress, and liver enzymes in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in C-reactive protein (CRP) and pro-oxidant-antioxidant balance (PAB) in the Lycopene group, but no significant differences in liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP) compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Eighty subjects with metabolic syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lycopene (LCP) supplementation could mitigate the adverse effects of a high-lipid diet (HLD) on lipid metabolism and growth in hybrid grouper.
results_summary: Lycopene improved growth metrics (weight gain rate, protein efficiency ratio) and reduced lipid deposition in the liver by enhancing lipolytic metabolism and decreasing fatty acid synthesis. The optimal dosage was found to be 200-300 mg/kg in the diet.
population_specificity: Hybrid grouper (♀ Epinephelus fuscoguttatus × ♂ E. lanceolatus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize High-Pressure Homogenization (HPH) parameters to enhance the recovery and bioaccessibility of bioactive compounds, including lycopene, from tomato pomace.
results_summary: HPH treatment under optimized conditions (80 MPa, 25 °C, 10 passes) significantly improved lycopene bioaccessibility during intestinal digestion, along with increased total phenolic content, antioxidant activity, and dietary fiber content compared to untreated samples.
population_specificity: Tomato processing by-products (in vitro study, no human participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (optimized HPH conditions: 80 MPa, 25 °C, 10 passes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a neuron-targeted lycopene delivery system to enhance mitochondrial function and mitophagy in Parkinson's disease models.
results_summary: The lycopene nanodots successfully enriched in neurons, improved mitochondrial function, promoted mitophagy, reduced α-synuclein pathology, and alleviated motor symptoms in Parkinson's model mice.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease model mice and in vitro neuronal models.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of lycopene on CCl4-induced hepatic fibrosis and elucidate its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: Lycopene significantly improved liver function, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and attenuated hepatic fibrosis by modulating autophagy-related pathways.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant effects of lycopene and its potential to inhibit the development of chronic diseases such as cardiovascular diseases, nervous system disorders, diabetes, liver diseases, and ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The study found that lycopene shows strong antioxidant activity and may help inhibit the development of chronic diseases linked to oxidative stress and inflammation. However, most supporting evidence comes from experimental research, with clinical studies being scarcer and less conclusive.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on chronic diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lycopene, alone and in combination with selenium, on male infertility associated with varicocele in rats.
results_summary: Lycopene alone significantly improved testis weight, testosterone levels, reduced apoptosis, and restored tubular organization in varicocele-induced rats. The combination of lycopene and selenium showed even better effects on biochemical and morphological parameters.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced varicocele.
study_duration: 28 days for initial assessment, with an additional month for some groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of lycopene extract, vitamin E extract, and their combination against oral pathogens for potential use in treating oral diseases.
results_summary: Lycopene extract showed substantial antimicrobial activity, with the highest efficacy at 100 μl concentration, particularly against C. albicans. The combination of lycopene and vitamin E had the strongest antimicrobial effect compared to either extract alone.
population_specificity: Oral commensals (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus mutans, Enterococcus faecalis, and Candida albicans).
effective_dosage: 25 μl, 50 μl, and 100 μl concentrations tested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the functional role of DcLCYB2 in carotenoid synthesis and its potential for engineering biofortified crops and crops resilient to saline environments.
results_summary: The study found that DcLCYB2 increases total carotenoid content in transgenic plants and enhances salt tolerance in tobacco and kiwi. Transgenic plants showed better performance under chronic salt treatment compared to controls.
population_specificity: Transgenic tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum) and kiwi (Actinidia deliciosa) plants and calli.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lycopene could mitigate peanut allergy symptoms by modulating the PI3K/AKT pathway and IgE-mediated reactions in a mouse model.
results_summary: Lycopene reduced PPE-specific IgE and IL-13 levels, alleviated small intestine inflammation, decreased histamine and mast cell protease-1 production, and downregulated PI3K/AKT1 expression in peanut-allergic mice.
population_specificity: Mice with crude peanut protein extract (PPE)-induced allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of nano-liposomal Lycopene (Lip-Lyco) in preventing obesity, insulin resistance, and NAFL progression in rats.
results_summary: Lip-Lyco counteracted obesity, insulin resistance, oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and inhibited the Hedgehog pathway in NAFL-induced rats, demonstrating antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, hypoglycemic, and autophagy-inducing effects.
population_specificity: Rats induced with NAFL via a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic and performance-enhancing effects of lycopene, including its roles in cancer therapy, immune modulation, livestock productivity, antioxidant activity, and fertility improvement.
results_summary: Lycopene demonstrated efficacy in enhancing broiler performance, alleviating heat stress by boosting antioxidant enzyme activity, improving fertility, reducing inflammation, and modulating immune responses under various challenges like AFB1 and lipopolysaccharide exposure.
population_specificity: Broilers (livestock) and general therapeutic applications (implied but not specified for humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lycopene could protect against zearalenone-induced uterine damage and pregnancy impairment in early pregnancy and explore its mechanism.
results_summary: Lycopene alleviated zearalenone-induced uterine damage, improved hormonal balance, reduced oxidative stress, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines, and enhanced anti-inflammatory responses. It also restored uterine cell homeostasis via the mitochondrial apoptosis pathway.
population_specificity: Pregnant subjects (animal model, likely rodents, based on methodology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, stability, and therapeutic potential of different lycopene formulations (LEG, LPG, nanoLPG) in treating chronic illnesses, focusing on liver function, cytotoxicity, antioxidant activity, and immune-related gene expression.
results_summary: LEG reduced hepatic degenerative changes in hypercholesterolemic hamsters but did not improve blood markers of liver function. LPG and nanoLPG showed no cytotoxicity in Vero cells, potent antioxidant activity, and vasoprotective effects, though moderate toxicity to keratinocytes was observed. NanoLPG demonstrated stability and altered immune-related gene expression in PBMCs.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolemic hamsters, Vero cells, human keratinocytes, isolated rat aorta, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective effects of Lycopene (LYC) against liver damage induced by 3,6-dichlorocarbazole (3,6-DCCZ) in yellow catfish.
results_summary: LYC treatment alleviated 3,6-DCCZ-induced liver damage by reducing oxidative stress, autophagy, inflammation, and apoptosis, primarily through inhibition of the ROS/PI3K-AKT/NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Yellow catfish (Pelteobagrus fulvidraco)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different emulsifiers (soy lecithin, sodium caseinate, and their combination) affect the physicochemical properties, stability, and bioaccessibility of lycopene nanodispersions under varying environmental conditions.
results_summary: Soy lecithin-stabilized nanodispersions showed the highest physical stability and smallest particle size under neutral pH, while sodium caseinate-stabilized ones were least stable. The combination of soy lecithin and sodium caseinate improved lycopene concentration and bioaccessibility. Stability varied with pH, ionic strength, and temperature, with soy lecithin performing best overall.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene could mitigate H2O2-induced oxidative stress injury in human vascular endothelial cells (VECs) by examining its effects on cell proliferation, cytotoxicity, inflammation, and apoptosis.
results_summary: Lycopene intervention counteracted H2O2-induced oxidative damage in VECs by reducing ROS levels, inflammatory factors, cell adhesiveness, and apoptosis, while activating the SIRT1/Nrf2/HO-1 pathway in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Human vascular endothelial cells (HMEC-1 and ECV-304 cell lines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which lycopene regulates islet function in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and its potential protective effects against islet inflammation and apoptosis.
results_summary: Lycopene suppressed islet inflammation and apoptosis, improved insulin secretion, reduced fasting blood glucose levels, and enhanced lipid profiles in diabetic mice and Min6 cells. These effects were linked to the down-regulation of the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: High-fat diet/streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice and Min6 cells exposed to high glucose/palmitic acid (HG/PA)-RAW264.7 conditioned medium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lycopene supplementation on performance, immune response, and histological parameters in heat-stressed growing rabbits.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation improved final body weight, body gain, feed conversion ratio, reduced liver TNF-α levels, enhanced immune responses, and positively affected liver and intestinal histology in heat-stressed rabbits.
population_specificity: Male V-line growing rabbits (5 weeks old, average weight 772.02 ± 6.41 g) under thermal stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects and underlying mechanisms of Lycopene-loaded microemulsion (LME) in mitigating Aβ-induced neurotoxicity in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: LME supplementation significantly reduced neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, apoptosis, and Aβ-related pathology while improving synaptic plasticity, whereas conventional Lycopene in olive oil (LOO) showed minimal effects. The study highlights the superior therapeutic efficacy of brain-targeted LME over LOO in countering Aβ-induced neurotoxicity.
population_specificity: Intracerebroventricular Aβ1-42 injection mice (animal model of Alzheimer's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lycopene (LYC) could prevent Di-n-butyl phthalate (DBP)-induced male reproductive toxicity, specifically testosterone synthesis inhibition.
results_summary: The study found that LYC supplementation reversed DBP-induced inhibition of testosterone synthesis by restraining the ROS/JAK2/STAT3 signaling pathway, reducing mitophagy and apoptosis, and improving testosterone production.
population_specificity: Male subjects (in vitro and in vivo models, exact species not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the therapeutic efficacy of lycopene (LYC) on testicular damage caused by inflammation and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: LYC administration inhibited cytokine excess and oxidative stress in the testes, mitigated testicular damage, and regulated lipid metabolism-related signaling pathways, including the PPAR pathway. Lipidomic and RNA sequencing analyses identified significant changes in lipids and genes involved in fatty acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Mature male rats with LPS-induced testicular inflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability and bio-accessibility of lycopene in emulsions stabilized by whey protein isolate (WPI) modified with high methoxylated pectin (HMP) and/or chlorogenic acid (CA).
results_summary: The study found that both binary and ternary complexes (WPI-HMP, WPI-CA, WPI-HMP-CA) enhanced emulsion stability and lycopene retention under UV irradiation, thermal treatment, and storage. In vitro digestion showed higher bio-accessibility of lycopene in emulsions stabilized by modified WPI compared to unmodified WPI.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanism of lycopene's anti-gastric cancer effects and its selective impact on gastric cancer cells versus normal cells.
results_summary: Lycopene suppressed cell growth, induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, and lowered mitochondrial membrane potentials in gastric cancer cells (AGS and SGC-7901) but not in normal gastric epithelial cells (GES-1). It also modulated key genes (CCNE1 and TP53) in cancer cells without affecting normal cells.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cell lines (AGS, SGC-7901, Hs746T) and normal gastric epithelial cell line (GES-1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different oil fractions in CNF-based Pickering emulsions affect the release of lycopene during gastrointestinal digestion.
results_summary: Higher oil fractions in CNF-based Pickering emulsions decreased lipolysis and controlled lycopene release during digestion, suggesting improved bioavailability. The release of lycopene mirrored free fatty acid (FFA) release patterns.
population_specificity: In vitro digestion model (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antioxidant and anticancer activities of lycopene samples with varying ratios of Z-isomers (5%, 30%, and 55%).
results_summary: Lycopene with 55% Z-isomers showed the highest bio-accessibility, antioxidant activity, and inhibition of hepatocellular carcinoma cells (HepG2). Molecular docking revealed higher binding affinity of Z-isomers to SR-BI, explaining their enhanced bioavailability.
population_specificity: Human hepatocellular carcinoma cells (HepG2) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate lycopene's function in ameliorating pelvic venous congestion (PC)-induced phenotypes and its anti-inflammatory effects in a rat model.
results_summary: Lycopene treatment improved locomotor activity, reduced urinary frequency, elevated urinary NOx levels, and decreased urinary 8-OHdG levels in PC rats. It also inhibited pro-inflammatory mediator expression and NF-κB signaling pathway activity.
population_specificity: Rats with induced pelvic venous congestion (PC).
effective_dosage: Not specified (administered intragastrically with olive oil daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effect of lycopene, alone and in combination with curcumin, on benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: Combination treatment with lycopene and curcumin significantly reduced prostate hyperplasia, improved BPH pathological features, and lowered inflammatory markers and hormone levels in rats. Lycopene alone also showed inhibitory effects, though the combination was more effective.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats and BPH-1 cell line (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer mechanisms of lycopene by reviewing in vivo and in vitro studies, focusing on its molecular and cellular effects in various tumors.
results_summary: The study found that lycopene exhibits anticancer potential through multiple mechanisms, including quenching singlet oxygen, stimulating antioxidant enzymes, inducing apoptosis, inhibiting cell proliferation, and modulating signaling pathways. The effects were influenced by factors like dose, delivery systems, cancer type, tumor size, and treatment duration.
population_specificity: Various in vitro cells, animal models, and some clinical trials (specific human populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Lycopene (LYC) could ameliorate the toxic effects of Atrazine (ATR) on the hippocampus, specifically focusing on learning and memory impairments and ferroptosis.
results_summary: LYC effectively mitigated ATR-induced hippocampus-dependent learning and memory impairments by inhibiting ferroptosis, improving lipid metabolism homeostasis, and increasing the expression of HO-1, Nrf2, and SLC7A11.
population_specificity: Male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lycopene supplementation on early weaning stress in piglets, focusing on oxidative stress, gut barrier function, and gut microbiota.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation improved antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced oxidative stress markers, enhanced intestinal barrier function, and modulated gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria and decreasing pathogenic bacteria.
population_specificity: 21-day-old weaned piglets (Duroc × (Landrace × Yorkshire); castrated males; initial body weight 5.48 ± 0.10 kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms of a lycopene-loaded nanoemulsion (nanoLPG) on human keratinocytes (HaCaT cells) and compare its effects to purified lycopene (LPG).
results_summary: NanoLPG demonstrated antioxidant capacity, prevented DNA degradation, and showed greater inhibition of tyrosinase and elastase enzymes compared to LPG. While IL-8 levels increased significantly, cell viability and morphology were maintained, contrasting with endoplasmic reticulum stress and autophagic vacuoles observed with LPG treatment.
population_specificity: Human keratinocytes (HaCaT cells) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low plasma levels of lycopene increase sensitivity to radiation-induced DNA damage in prostate cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that prostate cancer patients with low lycopene levels had significantly higher radiation-induced DNA damage (micronucleus and nuclear bud frequencies) compared to controls. The effect was more pronounced when both selenium and lycopene levels were low.
population_specificity: 106 prostate cancer patients and 132 age-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anticancer potential of lycopene, its sources, extraction techniques, chemistry, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Lycopene exhibits promising anticancer activity across multiple cancer types by inhibiting apoptosis, cell proliferation, metastasis, and angiogenesis, and modulating signal transduction pathways. The review highlights its potential in treating pancreatic, breast, prostate, liver, gastric, ovarian, kidney, skin, intestine, brain, and spinal cord cancers.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential inhibitory effect of lycopene on biochemically recurrent prostate cancer, as seen through 18 F-fluciclovine PET/CT and serum prostate-specific antigen response.
results_summary: The study reported a case of biochemically recurrent prostate cancer showing treatment response to lycopene, correlating with serum prostate-specific antigen response and imaging findings. The results suggest lycopene may have a complementary therapeutic effect in this context.
population_specificity: A single case of biochemically recurrent prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the protective effects of tomato and lycopene on skin photodamage and photoaging in healthy subjects by reviewing existing population intervention experiments.
results_summary: Supplementation with tomato and lycopene significantly reduced skin erythema, pigmentation, and markers of photodamage (Δa*, MMP-1, ICAM-1) while increasing MED, skin thickness, and density, suggesting potential for preventing light-induced skin damage.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore lycopene's potential as an adjuvant therapeutic strategy in malaria by examining its antioxidant effects and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study highlights lycopene as a powerful antioxidant among carotenoids, suggesting its potential to mitigate oxidative stress in malaria, though direct clinical outcomes in malaria patients are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with malaria (general discussion, no specific cohort studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Lycopene (LYC) against palmitate (PA)-induced cardiotoxicity in female rats, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and cytoprotective properties.
results_summary: Lycopene reversed PA-induced cardiotoxicity, reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and lipid abnormalities while improving cardiac function and histology. The effects were dose-dependent, with higher doses showing more pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: Female rats
effective_dosage: 24 mg/kg and 48 mg/kg, administered for the last two weeks of the study
study_duration: 7 weeks (PA administered for 7 weeks; LYC administered for the last 2 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of lycopene and tomato consumption on cardiovascular risk factors, including lipid profile, glycemic control, blood pressure, inflammation, oxidative stress, and body weight.
results_summary: Lycopene consumption significantly reduced malondialdehyde (MDA) levels, indicating potential benefits for oxidative stress, but showed no significant effects on other cardiovascular risk factors like lipid profile, blood pressure, inflammation markers, or body weight.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 34 RCTs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel tomato-based supplement enriched with olive polyphenols and high cis-lycopene concentrations in improving prostate health and preventing age-related prostate diseases.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced prostate-cancer-promoting cytokines in animals, improved urinary symptoms and quality of life in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia, and suppressed carcinogenesis in a mouse model of prostate cancer. It also interfered with prostate cancer molecular signaling.
population_specificity: Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia and high-risk individuals for age-related prostate diseases (animal models included TRAMP mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of lycopene supplementation in cancer prevention and treatment based on in vivo studies.
results_summary: The study found that lycopene demonstrated anti-cancer activities, including regulation of oxidative and inflammatory processes, induction of apoptosis, and inhibition of cell division, angiogenesis, and metastasis formation. Most studies focused on prostate cancer, and the mechanisms varied by tumor location and lycopene storage capacity.
population_specificity: Human and animal studies (specific populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of lycopene supplementation on serum PSA levels in patients with non-metastatic prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant overall effect of lycopene on circulating PSA levels, but observed a significant reduction in PSA levels among patients with higher baseline PSA levels (≥6.5 µg/L).
population_specificity: Patients with non-metastatic prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of supplemental lycopene on PSA levels in men through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The pooled analysis of 6 studies showed no significant differences in PSA levels between subjects treated with lycopene or tomato extract containing lycopene and the control group. The study concluded that lycopene or tomato extract had no significant effect on PSA levels, but more consistent clinical trials with larger sample sizes are needed.
population_specificity: Men (specific population not further detailed in the abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lycopene supplementation on serum IGF-1 levels and cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: Lycopene intake was not associated with reduced serum IGF-1 levels overall, but significant effects were observed at doses >15 mg/d, for <12 weeks, in healthy individuals and patients aged ≥60 years. Lycopene also showed potential benefits for cardiac disorders.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and patients aged ≥60 years, including those with cardiac disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 14 mg daily lactolycopene supplementation for 12 weeks could improve sperm quality in healthy men.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in motile sperm concentration (primary endpoint) but observed significant improvements in fast progressive sperm proportion and sperm morphology. Plasma lycopene levels increased in the supplemented group.
population_specificity: Healthy male participants (n=60, with 56 completing the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of dietary or supplemental lycopene on cardiovascular risk factors through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found conflicting results regarding lycopene's effects on cardiovascular risk factors, with no significant differences observed in blood pressure and lipid levels between lycopene and control groups. Meta-analyses supported these findings, indicating variability in efficacy across different dosages and delivery methods.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of cardiovascular disease.
effective_dosage: 1.44 to 75 mg lycopene/day (not reported in 11 of 43 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of lycopene supplementation on spermatogram and seminal oxidative stress in infertile men with oligozoospermia.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation significantly improved sperm parameters (total count, concentration, motility) and oxidative stress biomarkers (total antioxidant capacity) compared to placebo. The effects remained significant after statistical adjustments.
population_specificity: 44 infertile men with oligozoospermia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review the nutritional reputation of Gac (Momordica cochinchinensis), including its composition, health impacts, and regulatory aspects, while addressing misinformation.
results_summary: The abstract highlights Gac's micronutrient properties but notes that supplementation offers no significant advantage for healthy populations. It emphasizes the need for scientific validation of claims and identifies gaps in data.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether selenium and lycopene supplementation increased the risk of prostate cancer or had a protective effect.
results_summary: The study found no statistical difference in prostate cancer incidence between the supplemented and control groups, with no evidence of increased risk or protective benefits from lycopene and selenium.
population_specificity: 209 patients with PSA ≥4 ng/ml or suspicion of prostate cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of a new noninvasive immunofluorescence skin test for lycopene quantification compared to traditional HPLC serum lycopene assays in volunteers undergoing lycopene supplementation.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation significantly increased serum lycopene levels (2.6- and 3.4-fold over control at 2 and 4 weeks, respectively) and correlated with increased immunofluorescence staining in skin samples. The new skin assay showed 80-86.6% agreement with HPLC results, suggesting its potential for rapid lycopene deficiency detection.
population_specificity: 32 healthy volunteers aged 30-40 years (15 lycopene-supplemented, 17 placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of tomato products and lycopene supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors through a systematic review and meta-analysis of intervention trials.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, while tomato products improved LDL-cholesterol, IL-6 levels, and endothelial function. No other outcomes were significantly affected.
population_specificity: Adult subjects over 18 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tomato-juice supplementation could improve risk factors associated with metabolic syndrome, such as inflammation, insulin resistance, and hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in inflammation, endothelial dysfunction, insulin resistance, and LDL levels, along with a slight increase in HDL, suggesting tomato-juice may alleviate metabolic syndrome risk factors.
population_specificity: 27 individuals diagnosed with metabolic syndrome (15 in the intervention group, 12 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Commercially available tomato-juice consumed 4 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lycopene on vascular function in cardiovascular disease (CVD) patients and healthy volunteers (HV).
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation improved endothelial function (EDV) by 53% in CVD patients but had no effect in HVs. No changes were observed in blood pressure, arterial stiffness, lipids, or hsCRP levels in either group.
population_specificity: 36 statin-treated CVD patients and 36 healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whole-tomato supplement lycopene could reduce prostate-specific antigen (PSA) velocity in selected prostate cancer patients.
results_summary: Lycopene supplementation led to a statistically significant decrease in PSA velocity, with an accelerated decline over time. No toxic side effects were observed, though some patients withdrew due to cancer progression or non-compliance.
population_specificity: Selected prostate cancer patients (n=20 initially, n=17 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relevance of plasma and prostate lycopene concentrations after a lycopene-enriched diet in patients with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) and assess its potential as a chemopreventive agent for prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found no overall benefits from a 6-month lycopene supplementation, as the progression rate of HGPIN to prostate cancer was similar to literature-reported rates. However, prostatic lycopene concentration below 1 ng/mg was associated with prostate cancer progression, suggesting its potential as a biomarker.
population_specificity: 32 patients diagnosed with high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN).
effective_dosage: 20-25 mg/day of lycopene (via 30 g/day of triple concentrated tomato paste).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerance and acceptance of tomato juice (TJ) at different doses and its effect on serum lycopene levels during radiotherapy in men with localized prostate cancer.
